question: Which structure of Hb can do function?
exp: In case of any protein, Primary & secondary structures -NO function. Function stas from Teiary structure.

question: Which of the following is an example of conjugated protein?
exp: Simple proteins are those that are made up of only amino acids. Conjugated proteins are combinations of protein with a non-protein pa, called prosthetic group Albumin is a simple protein. It may transpo metal ions. But there is no prosthetic group -> option a is excluded. Gluten, a protein composite of:- Prolamin (in wheat named gliadin) Glutelin(in wheat named glutenin) This is again a simple protein -> option b is excluded. Myoglobin contains heme prosthetic group. So, it is obviously a conjugated protein -> option c is the answer.

question: Which technique is used to study structure of molecules -
exp: In the question, they have not mentioned about the nature of structure such as 1o, 2o or 3o etc. In this case, consider teiary structure (3D structure). So, mark X-ray crystallography (X-ray crystallography can detect 3-D structure of any macromolecule). ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON THIS TOPIC Mass spectrometry: Best technique to determine-primary structure of proteins This technique is Qualitative as well as Quantitative Can detect post-translational modifications (like hydroxylation) or covalent modifications of enzymes (like phosphorylation and dephosphorylation) Can detect the exact molecular weight of the protein (as the name says - MASS).

question: Shoest peptide is:
exp: Shoest peptide is Angiotensin-III Made up of 7 amino acids, formed from Angiotensin-II after the removal of an amino acid from N-terminal Angiotensin III has same efficacy as Angiotensin II for the secretion of aldosterone.

question: Most abundant in bone -
exp: Most abundant protein in bones is collagen. Collagen is formed from glycine proline lysine Proline and lysine are hydroxylated to make OH-proline and OH-lysine. Now, you have to choose between option 2 and 3. As most of the proline in collagen is hydroxyated so best out of these two options is hydroxyproline. Extra information: OH-proline cause extensive hydrogen bonding and hence collagen provide strength to the bones.

question: Glutathione is a
exp: Glutathione is -glutamyl cysteinyl glycine, i.e. glutathione is a tripeptide made up of 3 aminoacyl residues - Glutamate, Cysteine, Glycine Gluta - Glutamate Thi- Sulfur containing (Cysteine) One- Glycine (1 C amino acid) Glutathione is the major intracellular reducing substance/anti-oxidant SH group of glutathione is responsible for its antioxidant function.

question: The peptide bond has all the following characteristics, EXCEPT:-
exp: A peptide bond is a special type of amide bond -Characteristics of peptide bond:- Planar Uncharged Takes pa in hydrogen bonding Trans in configuration Rigid, because of paial double bond character - no rotation is possible

question: How many amino acids are present in a single turn of a-helix?
exp: a-helix is a rod-like helical structure where peptide backbone wound around a long axis, the side chains (R groups) radiate outward N-H group of one amino acid is hydrogen bonded to the C=O group of the amino acid located four residues earlier along the protein sequence. This hydrogen bonding creates a right-handed spiral or helix (coiled, rod-like structure). Most of the naturally occurring a-helix are right-handed. One turn of a-helix contains 3.6 amino acids. Distance between two adjacent amino acids is 1.5 Adeg

question: Which of the following protein can't have quaternary structure?
exp: For quaternary structure to be present you need more than one polypeptide chain Albumin is a single polypeptide. So, the highest structure it can have is teiary structure. Hemoglobin & Immunoglobulin are tetramer - option b and c are excluded. Collagen has the quaternary structure of quaer staggered arrangement - option d is excluded. fig:-Quaer stagger arrangement of tropocollagen

question: Peptide bond is formed between:-
exp: Proteins are polypeptides Series of amino acids linked peptide bonds A peptide bond is a special type of amide bond between the a-carboxyl group of one amino acid and the a-amino group of the adjacent amino acid.
opa: Carboxyl group on one amino acid and the R-group of adjacent amino acid
opb: Carboxyl group on both amino acids
opc: Amino group on one amino acid and the carboxyl group of the adjacent amino acid
opd: The amino group of both amino acids

question: Which of the following amino acids shows a tendency to form a left-handed helix?
exp: All the amino acid in human proteins are L-amino acids. Glycine does not have a chiral carbon. So, there is no D or L-form for glycine. Because of this flexibility, Glycine can form left-handed helix like collagen helix. (Note: Collagen helix is NOT an alpha helix). A "chiral" molecule is one that is not superimposable with its mirror image. The only amino acid that does not have four different groups attached to the alpha carbon is glycine. So, it lacks chirality. The image shows Chirality:

question: Which of the following is NOT a protein misfolding disorder:
exp: Protein misfolding diseases are also known as proteopathies or protein conformational disorders or disorders of proteostasis. question: Alpha helix is stabilized by?
exp: Secondary Structure includes * Alpha helix * Beta pleated sheet * Beta bend or turn * Alpha chain in collagen (not alpha helix) Structure Bonds Primary structure Covalent/amide/peptide bond Secondary structure Hydrogen bonds Teiary structure Disulphide, Hydrogen, Hydrophobic and Ionic bond Quaternary structure Hydrogen, hydrophobic and ionic bond
